oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gordon-Oak Streets: National Register nomination form
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Staff at MTSU Center for Historic Preservation
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: National Register of Historic Places nomination form for the Gordon-Oak Streets Historic District in Dyersburg, Tennessee.

Located in Dyersburg, Tennessee, the Gordon-Oak Streets Historic District consists of a portion of the odd numbered side of the 700 block of Sampson Avenue; the 100 through 300 blocks of Oak Street; and the 100 through 300 blocks of Gordon Street. The development of Gordon and Oak Streets began in the 1910s and 1920s as a residential neighborhood for professionals and business owners. It is believed that a local contractor/builder named Gordon platted the area as a new neighborhood. Most of the buildings in the district were constructed from 1910 to 1940. The Gordon-Oak Streets neighborhood gained recognition as a historic district in 1992 for its early twentieth century domestic architecture.
